subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
author: Rj
full_text:
--0-1979610836-1241984193=:82729
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

The kind of compression that occurs during an email attachment is "lossless=
": it compress the file cleverly without losing information.=A0 For example=
, if I had a program in some .exe files, and I sent it over email, it could=
 compress it.=A0 But if it lost even one bit, the resulting exe file would =
not execute again after it was uncompressed on the other side.

This kind o=
f compression does things like looking for common patterns in the file, and=
 replacing them with a token.=A0 A rough example would be if it found "Howd=
y Neighbor" in a file 20 times, it could replace all the occurances with sa=
y $HN1.=A0 And also write a little dictionary in there someplace that says =
"$HN1=3DHowdy Neighbor".

When the file gets to its destination it can be u=
ncompressed, and all occurences of $HN1 are replaced with "Howdy Neighbor".=
=A0 So it was compressed (instead of 14 characters each, it only needed 4, =
plus the dictionary), but lost no data.

Some formats, like jpeg and mp3. a=
re not lossless.=A0 Depending on the level of compression, some level of da=
ta is lost, and so cannot be recovered or reconstructed later.

Rick



---=
 On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@...> wr=
ote:

From: April Abercrombie <april@...>
Subject:=
 Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sunda=
y, May 10, 2009, 10:26 AM











    
            
            


     =
 
      


Another thing:
=A0
I recently found this out. When you email a 
=
file, if it is not saved as a compressed format, the email filtering proces=
s 
will actually compress the file automatically.
=A0
So even if you have a=
ttached a wav. file, it 
will loose resolution over the email process. It w=
ill not sound exactly the same 
as the original wav. file. How much it diff=
ers depends on the size of the file 
you are attaching. If it is a very=A0l=
arge file, it will sound much 
different.
=A0
The only exception to this is=
 if the wav. 
file is small enough that the filtering process will ignore i=
t. It has to be 
pretty small though, like under 1=A0MB (I am not exactly s=
ure of the 
threshold).
=A0
The best way to share files over the 
internet=
=A0if you want them as close to the original as possible is to upload 
them=
 directly to a website.
=A0

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: 
  Rj =

  To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
  Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 10:54 AM
  Su=
bject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading 
  rules
  

  
  
  
    
    
      
=
Pixelization doesn't clean-up the data: it replaces 
        it.=A0 Imagine=
 taking a picture of a field of flowers, and beginning 
        to add leve=
ls or pixelization to the picture.=A0 Soon, you would not 
        be able =
to tell there were flowers there at all.=A0 You would see a 
        lot of=
 colored blocks.

Or in the other direction, imagine you are 
        looki=
ng at a competely randomize bunch of pixes on your screen: a 
        compl=
ete screen of truely random static snow.=A0 Pixelizing this, 
        after=
 a while, you would again start to see colored 
        blocks.

What's hap=
pening is that it is processing an area of the 
        image, taking (for =
instance) the average value of that entire area, and 
        replacing all=
 the blocks in that area with the average.=A0 In video 
        processing,=
 this would result in a field of multi-colored flowers being 
        repla=
ced by, for instance, a big greyish-bluish block, with no 
        resembla=
nce to flowers.=A0 In the noise example, it maybe replace all 
        the =
random pixels with another big greyish-bluish block.=A0 If you 
        did=
 not know beforehand what the original picture was, you couldn't tell 
    =
    whether your pixelized image was really a field of flowers, a chevy, th=
e 
        sky with clouds, or a random bunch of pixels.

It works the same=
 
        with the sound files.=A0 Taking something as complex as speech, a=
nd 
        replacing frequencies with their averages, loses the speech the=
 farther 
        you go, until you head strange fluctuating square waves.=
=A0 Doing the 
        same to random static will eventually produce the sa=
me thing.=A0 And 
        random fluctuating square waves can sound a bit l=
ike speech - or at 
        least, you could have fun sharing with each oth=
er what you thing they 
        'sound like'.

whole file in wav format then do my clips 
                as mp3. Then I h=
ave the original for analysis. 
                =A0
                As far =
as pixelization of non sounds/white noise whos to 
                say that=
 isnt being manipulated by them as well LOL. Water is a 
                fo=
rm of white noise. I seem to remember some experiments done

  with blank tapes/film, no recording=A0done yet there were 
              =

                 =
 
                  
                  
                  
                =
    
                    
                      Be a bit careful of formats=
 like mp3 if 
                        you are doing a detailed analysis of =
the sounds 
                        though.=A0=A0 While some formats (like =
wav) can 
                        store the audio very close to the way it =
was recorded, 
                        formats like mp3 compress the file, =
and in so doing lose 
                        some of the sonic details.=A0=
 This may not be a big 
                        deal in music, where the au=
dio is fairly clear to begin 
                        with.=A0 But with sou=
nd sources with a lot of noise 
                        (like evps), this c=
an not only obscure any real sounds, 
                        but pixelize =
non-sounds (like white noise) and make them 
                        start =
to sound like speech.

So mp3 might be good 
                        for sh=
aring the data, once you've already formed an 
                        opin=
ion based on an analysis of the wav file.=A0 But 
                        m=
p3 is not good as a medium for analysis.=A0 It can 
                       =
 lead to many false positives and 
                        misinterpretatio=
ns.

      <td valign=3D"top"><br>Pixeliz=
ation doesn't clean-up the data: it replaces 
        it.  Imagine tak=
ing a picture of a field of flowers, and beginning 
        to add levels o=
r pixelization to the picture.  Soon, you would not 
        be able t=
o tell there were flowers there at all.  You would see a 
        lot =
of colored blocks.<br><br>Or in the other direction, imagine you are 
     =
   looking at a competely randomize bunch of pixes on your screen: a 
     =
   complete screen of truely random static snow.  Pixelizing this, 
  =
      after a while, you would again start to see colored 
        blocks.<=
br><br>What's happening is that it is processing an area of the 
        im=
age, taking (for instance) the average value of that entire area, and 
    =
    replacing all the blocks in that area with the average.  In video =

        processing, this would result in a field of multi-colored flowers =
being 
        replaced by, for instance, a big greyish-bluish block, with =
no 
        resemblance to flowers.  In the noise example, it maybe re=
place all 
        the random pixels with another big greyish-bluish block.=
  If you 
        did not know beforehand what the original picture wa=
s, you couldn't tell 
        whether your pixelized image was really a fie=
ld of flowers, a chevy, the 
        sky with clouds, or a random bunch of =
pixels.<br><br>It works the same 
        with the sound files.  Takin=
g something as complex as speech, and 
        replacing frequencies with t=
heir averages, loses the speech the farther 
        you go, until you head=
 strange fluctuating square waves.  Doing the 
        same to random =
static will eventually produce the same thing.  And 
        random fl=
uctuating square waves can sound a bit like speech - or at 
        least, =
you could have fun sharing with each other what you thing they 
        'so=
und like'.<br><br><br><br><br><br>--- On <b>Sun, 5/10/09, Misty Dawn
